Joe Thomas ''(1st team)'' }} The '''[[2009 NFL season|2009]] [[Cleveland Browns]] [[List of Cleveland Browns seasons|season]]''' was the team's 63rd season as a professional sports franchise and its 59th season as a member of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). The team placed fourth in the [[AFC North]] with a record of 5â11, improving upon its [[2008 Cleveland Browns season|2008]] record of 4â12. This season marked [[George Kokinis]] and [[Eric Mangini]]'s first seasons as the team's [[general manager]] and [[head coach]], respectively; however, Kokinis was fired on November 2 during the team's Week 9 bye week.{{cite web|author=Mortensen, Chris and Adam Schefter |date=November 2, 2009 |title= Browns GM Kokinis ousted|work=ESPN|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4616312|accessdate=November 2, 2009}} The Browns played all of their home games at [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] in [[Cleveland, Ohio]]. The Browns missed the playoffs for the seventh straight season, tying a record set between 1973â79. {{TOC limit|limit=4}} == Offseason == === Personnel changes === On December 29, 2008, the Cleveland Browns announced that the team had fired general manager [[Phil Savage]] and head coach [[Romeo Crennel]] after spending four seasons together in Cleveland.{{cite web|title=Browns announce changes|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9338|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=December 29, 2008|accessdate=April 26, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgJSXQKM|archivedate=June 20, 2009|deadurl=no}} Crennel, who joined the Browns with Savage in 2005, left Cleveland with a record of 24â40 (.375) and an 0â8 record against the division rival [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. The team's best record under Crennel was 10â6 during the [[2007 Cleveland Browns season|2007 season]]. On January 7, 2009, the Browns announced that the team had found its replacement for Crennel and that it had reached a contractual agreement with former [[New York Jets]] head coach [[Eric Mangini]], who was fired after three seasons in New York.{{cite web|title=Browns, Mangini reach agreement|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9357|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=January 7, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Mangini, who joined the Jets in 2006, left New York with a record of 23â25 (.479), including a 10â6 record and a playoff appearance in his [[2006 New York Jets season|first season]]. On January 14, the Browns announced that Mangini had named his coordinators: [[Brian Daboll]] was hired as the offensive coordinator; [[Rob Ryan]] as the defensive coordinator; and [[Brad Seely]] as the special teams coordinator and assistant head coach.{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=January 22, 2009|title=Mangini names coordinators|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9371|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Daboll was most recently the quarterbacks coach for the Jets from 2007â2008; Ryan was the defensive coordinator for the [[Oakland Raiders]] from 2004â2008; and Seely was the special teams coach for the [[New England Patriots]] from 1999â2008. All three worked with Mangini from 2000â2003 as members of New England. Daboll, Ryan, and Seely replace [[Rob Chudzinski]], [[Mel Tucker]], and [[Ted Daisher]], respectively. On January 22, the Browns hired five assistant coaches: [[Bryan Cox]] was hired as the defensive line coach; Andy Dickerson as the defensive quality control coach; [[Jerome Henderson]] as the defensive backs coach; [[Rick Lyle]] as an assistant strength-and-conditioning coach; and [[Carl Smith (American football)|Carl Smith]] as the quarterbacks coach.{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=January 22, 2009|title=Browns announce hiring of 5 assistants|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9384|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Cox, Dickerson, Henderson, and Lyle spent the past three seasons with Mangini in New York. Smith was the Browns' quarterbacks coach from 2001â2003 and was most recently the offensive coordinator for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] from 2005â2006. On January 25, the Browns hired former [[Baltimore Ravens]] director of pro personnel [[George Kokinis]] as general manager.{{cite web|title=Browns announce hiring of Kokinis|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9385|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=January 25, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Kokinis spent five seasons in the Browns' scouting department from 1991â1995, and after the team moved to Baltimore, he was a member of the Ravens' scouting department from 1996â1999. He was the Ravens' assistant director of pro personnel from 2000â2002 and was the director of pro personnel from 2003â2008. On February 4, the Browns hired three more assistant coaches: [[Alan DeGennaro]] was hired as an assistant strength-and-conditioning coach; [[Tom Myslinski]] as the strength-and-conditioning coach; and George Warhop as the offensive line coach.{{cite web|title=Browns name 3 coaches|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9397|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=February 4, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On February 11, the Browns hired [[George McDonald (American football)|George McDonald]] as the offensive quality control coach.{{cite web|title=Browns hire McDonald|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9409|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=February 11, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On February 17, the Browns hired [[Gary Brown]] as the running backs coach and Steve Hagen as the tight ends coach.{{cite web|title=Browns add two coaches|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9413|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=February 17, 2009|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On February 22, the Browns hired Matt Eberflus as the linebackers coach.{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=February 22, 2009|title=Browns hire Missouri's Eberflus to coach linebackers|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80edffa6&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true|work=NFL.com|accessdate=April 26, 2009}} On May 6, the Browns promoted McDonald to wide receivers coach.{{cite web|author= |date=May 6, 2009|title=Browns promote McDonald|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9562|work=Clevelandbrowns.com|accessdate=May 10, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgJUa5XT|archivedate=2009-06-20|deadurl=no}} === Roster changes === ==== Free agents ==== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%; text-align: center;" |- ! {{Abbr|Pos|Position}} !! ==== Trades ==== On February 27, the Browns traded tight end [[Kellen Winslow II|Kellen Winslow]] to the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] for its second-round selection in the [[2009 NFL Draft]] (50th overall, used to select [[Mohamed Massaquoi]]) and its fifth-round selection in the [[2010 NFL Draft]].{{cite web|title=Winslow traded to Tampa Bay|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9440|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|date=February 27, 2009|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Winslow was selected sixth overall by the Browns in the first round of the [[2004 NFL Draft]] and played five seasons with the team. During his career with the Browns, he accumulated 219 receptions for 2,459 yards (11.2 YPC) and had eleven touchdown receptions. On April 25, during the first round of the [[2009 NFL Draft]], the team traded its first-round selection (5th overall) to the [[New York Jets|Jets]] for its first- (17th overall) and second-round (52nd overall) selections, defensive end [[Kenyon Coleman]], safety [[Abram Elam]], and quarterback [[Brett Ratliff]].{{cite web|Jackson, Zac|date=April 25, 2009|title=Browns trade down, add players|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=9522|work=ClevelandBrowns.com|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==== 2009 draft class ==== {{main|2009 NFL Draft}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! |work=Akron Beacon Journal |accessdate=June 16, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgJWAujb|archivedate=2009-06-20|deadurl=no}} |} === Legal troubles for WR Stallworth === On March 14, Browns wide receiver [[DontÃ© Stallworth]] was involved in a fatal accident in which he struck and killed pedestrian Mario Reyes with his car in the early morning in [[Miami]], [[Florida]].{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=March 14, 2009|title=Stallworth involved in fatal accident|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3980182|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} Stallworth then stopped his vehicle and called 9â1â1. Reports showed that Stallworth was driving under the influence; his blood-alcohol level was 0.12%, above Florida's legal limit of 0.08%.{{cite web|author=Associated Press|date=April 2, 2009|title=Stallworth charged in man's death|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4033632|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} He was charged with DUI manslaughter and a warrant was issued for his arrest on April 1 and he surrendered to police on April 2. On June 16, Stallworth pleaded guilty. He was sentenced to 30 days in prison, two years' house arrest, and eight years probation.{{cite web|author=Anderson, Curt |date=June 16, 2009 |title=WR Stallworth pleads guilty, gets 30 days in jail |url=http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=Ag03K74khn3mP_D7G55jtBU5nYcB?slug=ap-stallworth-pedestriankilled&prov=ap&type=lgns |accessdate=June 16, 2009|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hgJVlEno|archivedate=2009-06-20|deadurl=no}} Many believed that the sentence Stallworth received was too lenient{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} as he could have served up to 15 years in jail. Stallworth also reached an undisclosed financial settlement with the victim's family. On June 18, the NFL suspended Stallworth indefinitely{{cite news|author=Smith, Joe |date=June 18, 2009 |title=Browns WR Stallworth suspended indefinitely by NFL |url=http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=ArPmU93kTVuOTqFy0pAd0GY5nYcB?slug=ap-browns-stallworthsuspended&prov=ap&type=lgns |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=June 18, 2009}} On August 13, the NFL officially suspended Stallworth for the entire 2009 season, and made plans to reinstate him after the Super Bowl. === Uniform changes === In 2009, the Cleveland Browns are wearing brown pants for games in which they wear white jerseys. These were worn in the 2008 pre-season. 17 | January 3 || 1:00 pm || '''[[Jacksonville Jaguars]]''' || style="text-align:center;"| '''W''' 23â17 || style="text-align:center;"| 5â11 || Cleveland Browns Stadium || CBS || [http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2010010302/2009/REG17/jaguars@browns Recap] |} === Standings === {{2009 AFC North standings}} === Regular season results === ==== Week 1: vs. Minnesota Vikings ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Vikings''' |R1=3||R2=7||R3=14||R4=10||RT=34 |Home=Browns |H1=3||H2=10||H3=0||H4=7||HT=20 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 70 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 70,560 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]], [[Brian Billick]], & [[Charissa Thompson]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 11:33 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 37 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 0:06 MIN â [[Ryan Longwell|Longwell]] 21 yard field goal 3â3 '''2nd Quarter''' * 11:17 MIN â [[Adrian Peterson|Peterson]] 1 yard run (Longwell kick) 10â3 MIN * 6:00 CLE â Dawson 20 yard field goal 10â6 MIN * 1:46 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 67 yard punt return (Dawson kick) 13â10 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:10 MIN â Peterson 1 yard run (Longwell kick) 17â13 MIN * 1:12 MIN â [[Percy Harvin|Harvin]] 6 yard pass from [[Brett Favre|Favre]] (Longwell kick) 24â13 MIN '''4th Quarter''' * 6:59 MIN â Longwell 37 yard field goal 27â13 MIN * 6:11 MIN â Peterson 64 yard run (Longwell kick) 34â13 MIN * 0:35 CLE â [[Robert Royal|Royal]] 26 yard pass from [[Brady Quinn|Quinn]] (Dawson kick) 34â20 MIN }} The Browns opened their season at home against the Minnesota Vikings trying to improve on their 4â12 record from last season. After trading field goals in the first quarter, RB [[Adrian Peterson]] scored the first touchdown of the game, giving Minnesota a 10â3 lead. But K [[Phil Dawson]] kicked his second field goal and WR Josh Cribbs returned a punt for a touchdown and the Browns took a 13â10 lead into halftime. However, the second half was controlled completely by the Vikings, with QB [[Brett Favre]] connecting with WR [[Percy Harvin]] for Favre's first touchdown pass as a Viking. In the 4th quarter, QB [[Brady Quinn]] completed a touchdown pass to TE [[Robert Royal]], the first touchdown by Cleveland's offense since the 4th quarter of Week 11 in 2008, ending a span of 416 offensive plays without a touchdown. With the loss, Cleveland fell to 0â1. ==== Week 2: at Denver Broncos ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=6||R2=0||R3=0||R4=0||RT=6 |Home='''Broncos''' |H1=7||H2=3||H3=3||H4=14||HT=27 |stadium= [[Invesco Field at Mile High]], [[Denver, Colorado]] |time= 4:15 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/2:15 pm [[Mountain Time Zone|MDT]] |weather= 82 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 73,931 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Bill Macatee]] & [[Steve Beuerlein]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 12:25 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 22 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 8:07 DEN â [[Tony Scheffler|Scheffler]] 2 yard pass from [[Kyle Orton|Orton]] ([[Matt Prater|Prater]] kick) 7â3 DEN * 1:53 CLE â Dawson 47 yard field goal 7â6 DEN '''2nd Quarter''' * 11:45 DEN â Prater 23 yard field goal 10â6 DEN '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:43 DEN â Prater 38 yard field goal 13â6 DEN '''4th Quarter''' * 12:22 DEN â [[Peyton Hillis|Hillis]] 2 yard run (Prater kick) 20â6 DEN * 8:35 DEN â [[Correll Buckhalter|Buckhalter]] 45 yard run (Prater kick) 27â6 DEN }} Hoping to rebound from their home loss to the Vikings, the Browns flew to [[Invesco Field at Mile High]] for a Week 2 duel with the [[Denver Broncos]]. After recovering a fumble on the opening kickoff, the Browns started with a short field but couldn't capitalize, settling for a 22-yard field goal by kicker [[Phil Dawson]]. Broncos quarterback [[Kyle Orton]] would complete a 2-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Tony Scheffler]] for the game's first touchdown, and after a 47-yard field goal by Cleveland, the game was 7â6 after the first quarter. However, Cleveland's offensive struggles continued. Meanwhile, in the second and third quarter, kicker [[Matt Prater]] gave Denver a 23-yard and a 38-yard field goal. Afterwards, in the fourth quarter, the Broncos took control with touchdown runs by [[Peyton Hillis]] and [[Correll Buckhalter]]. With the loss, the Browns fell to 0â2. ==== Week 3: at Baltimore Ravens ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0||R2=0||R3=0||R4=3||RT=3 |Home='''Ravens''' |H1=10||H2=10||H3=7||H4=7||HT=34 |stadium= [[M&T Bank Stadium]], [[Baltimore, Maryland]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 72 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,950 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 10:19 BAL â [[Willis McGahee|McGahee]] 7 yard run ([[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] kick) 7â0 BAL * 1:21 BAL â Hauschka 36 yard field goal 10â0 BAL '''2nd Quarter''' * 5:42 BAL â Hauschka 33 yard field goal 13â0 BAL * 1:01 BAL â McGahee 15 yard run (Hauschka kick) 20â0 BAL '''3rd Quarter''' * 7:38 BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 9 yard run (Hauschka kick) 27â0 BAL '''4th Quarter''' * 15:00 CLE â [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 29 yard field goal 27â3 BAL * 8:18 BAL â [[Derrick Mason|Mason]] 72 yard pass from [[Joe Flacco|Flacco]] (Hauschka kick) 34â3 BAL }} Hoping to rebound from their road loss to the Broncos, the Browns flew to [[M&T Bank Stadium]] for a Week 3 AFC North duel with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Cleveland would trail early in the first quarter as Ravens running back [[Willis McGahee]] got a 7-yard touchdown run, followed by kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] getting a 36-yard field goal. The Browns' deficit would increase in the second quarter as Hauschka nailed a 33-yard field goal, while McGahee got a 15-yard touchdown run. In the third quarter, things continued to get worse for the Browns as running back [[Ray Rice]] got a 9-yard touchdown run. In thr fourth quarter, Cleveland would manage to get on the board as kicker [[Billy Cundiff]] made a 29-yard field goal. Afterwards, Baltimore closed out the game as quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] completed a 72-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Derrick Mason]]. With the loss, the Browns fell to 0â3. Starting quarterback [[Brady Quinn]] (6 of 8, 34 yards, 1 INT) was benched after a dismal first half performance, while [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] (11 of 19, 92 yards, 3 INTs) did not perform much better. ==== Week 4: vs. Cincinnati Bengals ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bengals''' |R1=7||R2=7||R3=0||R4=6||R5=3||RT=23 |Home=Browns |H1=0||H2=7||H3=7||H4=6||H5=0||HT=20 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 58 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 69,844 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 0:40 CIN â [[Chad Ochocinco|Ochocinco]] 5 yard pass fron [[Carson Palmer|Palmer]] ([[Shayne Graham|Graham]] kick) 7â0 CIN '''2nd Quarter''' * 14:26 CIN â [[Robert Geathers|Geathers]] 75 yard fumble return (Graham kick) 14â0 CIN * 1:33 CLE â [[Steve Heiden|Heiden]] 1 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] ([[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] kick) 14â7 CIN '''3rd Quarter''' * 1:44 CLE â Anderson 1 yard run (Cundiff kick) 14â14 '''4th Quarter''' * 15:00 CLE â Cundiff 26 yard field goal 17â14 CLE * 6:38 CLE â Cundiff 31 yard field goal 20â14 CLE * 2:02 CIN â Ochocinco 2 yard pass from Palmer 20â20 '''Overtime''' * 0:07 CIN â Graham 31 yard field goal 23â20 CIN }} Still looking for their first win of the season, the Browns went home for a Week 4 AFC North duel with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in Round 1 of 2009's [[Battle of Ohio (NFL)|Battle of Ohio]]. Due to quarterback [[Brady Quinn]]'s poor performance in the season thus far, head coach [[Eric Mangini]] named quarterback [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] the starter. Cleveland would trail early in the first quarter as Bengals quarterback [[Carson Palmer]] completed a 5-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Chad Ochocinco]]. The Browns would continue to struggle in the second quarter as defensive end [[Robert Geathers]] returned a fumble 75 yards for a touchdown. Cleveland would respond with Anderson completing a 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Steve Heiden]]. The Browns would tie the game in the third quarter with Anderson's 1-yard touchdown run. Afterwards, Cleveland would take the lead in the fourth quarter with a 26-yard and a 31-yard field goal from kicker [[Billy Cundiff]]. However, Cincinnati answered with Palmer hooking up with Ochocinco again on a 2-yard touchdown run (with a blocked PAT). In overtime, both teams went back and forth with their possessions. In the end, the Bengals emerged victorious with kicker [[Shayne Graham]] kicking the game-winning 31-yard field goal. With the loss, the Browns fell to 0â4. ==== WR Edwards traded ==== [[File:20090806 Braylon Edwards.jpg|upright|thumb|Edwards (shown in 2009 training camp) was traded to the [[New York Jets]] during the season.]] On October 7, the Browns traded WR [[Braylon Edwards]] to the [[New York Jets]] for WR [[Chansi Stuckey]], LB [[Jason Trusnik]], and third- and fifth- round selections in the [[2010 NFL Draft]]. The third-round selection would have become a second-round selection based on Edwards met certain performance criteria with the Jets this season, but he did not meet those criteria.{{cite web|author=McMorrow, Kyle |date=October 7, 2009 |title= Cleveland Deals Troubled Wide Receiver Braylon Edwards to New York Jets|work=Bleacher Report|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/267934-cleavland-deals-troubled-wide-receiver-to-the-new-york-jets |accessdate=October 7, 2009}} ==== Week 5: at Buffalo Bills ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Browns''' |R1=0||R2=3||R3=0||R4=3||RT=0 |Home=Bills |H1=0||H2=0||H3=3||H4=0||HT=0 |stadium= [[Ralph Wilson Stadium]], [[Orchard Park (town), New York|Orchard Park, New York]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 47 Â°F (Mostly Sunny) |attendance= 70,526 |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Don Criqui]] & [[Randy Cross]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''2nd Quarter''' * 7:31 CLE â [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 24 yard field goal 3â0 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:15 BUF â [[Rian Lindell|Lindell]] 36 yard field goal 3â3 '''4th Quarter''' * 0:26 CLE â Cundiff 18 yard field goal 6â3 CLE }} After a heartbreaking loss to the Bengals, the Browns headed to Buffalo, the site of their last win in Week 11 of the 2008 season, and trying to avoid tying a franchise record 11 straight losses. In very windy conditions, the Browns' hero was punter [[Dave Zastudil]] who pinned the Bills within their 5 yard line 3 times. After trading field goals in the 2nd and 3rd quarters, the Browns recovered a fumble on a punt return by WR [[Roscoe Parrish]], and kicker [[Billy Cundiff]] secured the victory with a short field goal. The Browns won despite QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] completing only 2 of 17 passes (11.8%) for 23 yards, setting a record for lowest completion percentage in a win since the [[AFL-NFL merger]]. This also marked [[Eric Mangini]]'s first win as head coach of the Browns. With the win, the Browns improved to 1â4. Zastudil was named the AFC special teams player of the week.[http://www.woio.com/global/story.asp?s=11314816 Dave Zastudil Named AFC Player Of The Week] ==== Week 6: at Pittsburgh Steelers ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0||R2=7||R3=7||R4=0||RT=14 |Home='''Steelers''' |H1=0||H2=17||H3=7||H4=3||HT=27 |stadium= [[Heinz Field]], [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 41 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 64,398 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''2nd Quarter''' * 11:35 PIT â [[Heath Miller|Miller]] 8 yard pass from [[Ben Roethlisberger|Roethlisberger]] ([[Jeff Reed (American football)|Reed]] kick) 7â0 PIT * 4:38 PIT â [[Hines Ward|Ward]] 52 yard pass from Roethlisberger (Reed kick) 14â0 PIT * 4:28 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 98 yard kickoff return ([[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] kick) 14â7 PIT * 0:10 PIT â Reed 32 yard field goal 17â7 PIT '''3rd Quarter''' * 11:43 CLE â [[Lawrence Vickers|Vickers]] 1 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Cundiff kick) 17â14 PIT * 8:39 PIT â [[Rashard Mendenhall|Mendenhall]] 2 yard run (Reed kick) 24â14 PIT '''4th Quarter''' * 5:47 PIT â Reed 39 yard field goal 27â14 PIT }} After securing their first win of the season, the Browns went on the road to take on their archrival [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. The Browns came into the game having lost their last 11 games against the Steelers. The Steelers struck first with two touchdown passes from [[Ben Roethlisberger]] in the 2nd quarter. [[Josh Cribbs]] ran a kickoff back 98 yards for a touchdown, and got the Browns within 7. However, the Browns could never close the gap, and fell to the Steelers, 27â14. With the loss, the Browns fell to 1â5. ==== Week 7: vs. Green Bay Packers ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=0||R2=21||R3=3||R4=7||RT= |Home=Browns |H1=0||H2=3||H3=0||H4=0||HT= |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 50 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 69,797 |referee= [[Don Carey (official)|Don Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]] & [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''2nd Quarter''' * 14:58 CLE â [[Billy Cundiff|Cundiff]] 22 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 12:11 GB â [[Spencer Havner|Havner]] 45 yard pass from [[Aaron Rodgers|Rodgers]] ([[Mason Crosby|Crosby]] kick) 7â3 GB * 7:01 GB â [[Donald Driver|Driver]] 71 yard pass from Rodgers (Crosby kick) 14â3 GB * 1:56 GB â [[Ryan Grant|Grant]] 1 yard run (Crosby kick) 21â3 GB '''3rd Quarter''' * 3:34 GB â Crosby 18 yard field goal 24â3 GB '''4th Quarter''' * 9:42 GB â [[James Jones (wide receiver)|Jones]] 5 yard pass from Rodgers (Crosby kick) 31â3 GB }} Hoping to rebound from their road loss to the Steelers, the Browns went home for a Week 7 interconference duel with the [[Green Bay Packers]]. After a scoreless first quarter, Cleveland began the second quarter with kicker [[Billy Cundiff]]'s 22-yard field goal. However, the Packers would take charge with quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] completing a 45-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Spencer Havner]] and a 71-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Donald Driver]], followed by a 1-yard touchdown run by running back [[Ryan Grant]]. Afterwards, Green Bay pulled away in the second half with kicker [[Mason Crosby]] booting an 18-yard field goal in the third quarter and Rodgers finding wide receiver [[James Jones (wide receiver)|James Jones]] on a 5-yard touchdown pass. With the loss, the Browns stumbled to 1â6. ==== Week 8: at Chicago Bears ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0||R2=0||R3=6||R4=0||RT=6 |Home='''Bears''' |H1=6||H2=10||H3=7||H4=7||HT=30 |stadium= [[Soldier Field]], [[Chicago, Illinois]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/12:00 pm [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 50 Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 62,262 |referee= [[Alberto Riveron]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 2:25 CHI â [[Robbie Gould|Gould]] 37 yard field goal 3â0 CHI * 1:18 CHI â Gould 29 yard field goal 6â0 CHI '''2nd Quarter''' * 8:48 CHI â Gould 32 yard field goal 9â0 CHI * 2:00 CHI â [[Matt FortÃ©|FortÃ©]] 1 yard run (Gould kick) 16â0 CHI '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:35 CLE â [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] 1 yard run 16â6 CHI * 1:49 CHI â FortÃ© 10 yard run (Gould kick) 23â6 CHI '''4th Quarter''' * 3:25 CHI â [[Charles Tillman|Tillman]] 21 yard interception return (Gould kick) 30â6 CHI }} Trying to snap a two-game losing streak, the Browns flew to [[Soldier Field]] for a Week 8 interconference duel with the [[Chicago Bears]]. The Browns' defense held up well early, limiting the Bears to three field goals by kicker [[Robbie Gould]] (a 37-yard & a 29-yard in the first quarter and a 32-yard in the second). However, the Browns could not manage to get on the board and Chicago RB [[Matt FortÃ©]] scored on a 1-yard run, putting the Browns down 16 at the half. The Browns struck first in the third quarter on a one yard run by QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]], but the PAT was blocked. FortÃ© scored again in the third with a 10-yard touchdown run and the Bears put the Browns away with a 21-yard interception return for a touchdown by CB [[Charles Tillman]] in the fourth quarter. Late in the fourth, Derek Anderson was benched for [[Brady Quinn]] after going 6 of 17 (35.2%) for 76 yards and 2 interceptions. With the loss, the Browns went into their bye week at 1â7. ==== GM Kokinis fired ==== On November 2, the Browns fired general manager [[George Kokinis]] after getting off to a disappointing 1â7 start. The Browns' statement said that Kokinis "is no longer actively involved with the organization." Owner [[Randy Lerner]] reportedly asked for his resignation, and when Kokinis refused, sought a dismissal "for cause." Head coach [[Eric Mangini]] was told by Lerner that his job was safe for the moment. ==== Week 10: vs. Baltimore Ravens ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1=0||R2=0||R3=16||R4=0||RT=16 |Home=Browns |H1=0||H2=0||H3=0||H4=0||HT=0 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:30 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 46 Â°F (Chilly) |attendance= 69,023 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[Monday Night Football|ESPN]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Jon Gruden]] & [[Michelle Tafoya]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''3rd Quarter''' * 12:35 BAL â [[Ray Rice|Rice]] 13 yard run ([[Steven Hauschka|Hauschka]] kick) 7â0 BAL * 12:20 BAL â [[Dawan Landry|Landry]] 48 yard interception return 13â0 BAL * 7:25 BAL â Hauschka 44 yard field goal 16â0 BAL }} The Browns came out of their bye week with [[Brady Quinn]] as the starting quarterback again and looking to turn around their disappointing season. They hosted the [[Baltimore Ravens]] on [[Monday Night Football]]. Both teams played a scoreless first half, the first scoreless half in the NFL this season and only the ninth ever in 620 Monday Night Football games. The Ravens took over in the third with two touchdowns in 15 seconds (a 13-yard touchdown run from running back [[Ray Rice]] and safety [[Dawan Landry]]'s 48-yard interception return for a touchdown). Kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] would add a 44-yard field goal, and the Browns could not score. This was the Browns' first shutout of the year. With the loss, the Browns fell to 1â8. ==== Week 11: at Detroit Lions ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=24||R2=3||R3=2||R4=8||RT=37 |Home='''Lions''' |H1=10||H2=14||H3=7||H4=7||HT=38 |stadium= [[Ford Field]], [[Detroit, Michigan]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= None (Domed Stadium) |attendance= 43,170 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Don Criqui]] & [[Randy Cross]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 11:34 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 44 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 9:17 DET â [[Jason Hanson|Hanson]] 31 yard field goal 3â3 * 9:05 CLE â [[Mohamed Massaquoi|Massaquoi]] 59 yard pass from [[Brady Quinn|Quinn]] (Dawson kick) 10â3 CLE * 4:10 CLE â [[Chansi Stuckey|Stuckey]] 40 yard pass from Quinn (Dawson kick) 17â3 CLE * 2:57 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 4 yard pass from Quinn 24â3 CLE * 0:37 DET â [[Aaron Brown (running back)|Brown]] 26 yard pass from [[Matthew Stafford|Stafford]] (Hanson kick) 24â10 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 11:52 DET â [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Smith]] 25 yard pass from Stafford (Hanson kick) 24â17 CLE * 5:12 DET â [[Calvin Johnson (American football)|Johnson]] 75 yard pass from Stafford (Hanson kick) 24â24 * 0:06 CLE â Dawson 29 yard field goal 27â24 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 2:52 DET â [[Will Heller|Heller]] 1 yard pass from Stafford (Hanson kick) 31â27 DET * 0:47 CLE â intentional grounding in the end zone 31â29 DET '''4th Quarter''' * 5:51 CLE â [[Michael Gaines|Gaines]] 2 yard pass from Quinn ([[Jamal Lewis|Lewis]] run) 37â31 CLE * 0:00 DET â [[Brandon Pettigrew|Pettigrew]] 1 yard pass from Stafford (Hanson kick) 38â37 DET }} Looking to snap a four-game losing streak, the Browns flew to [[Ford Field]] for a Week 11 interconference duel with the [[Detroit Lions]]. Both teams began the game with field goals, as Cleveland kicker [[Phil Dawson]] made a 44-yard field goal while Lions kicker [[Jason Hanson]] got a 31-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Browns' offense exploded as quarterback [[Brady Quinn]] completed a 59-yard touchdown pass to rookie wide receiver [[Mohamed Massaquoi]], a 40-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Chansi Stuckey]], and a 4-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver Josh Cribbs. Detroit would answer with quarterback [[Matthew Stafford]] completing a 26-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Aaron Brown (running back)|Aaron Brown]]. The Lions would tie the game in the second quarter as Stafford hooked up with running back [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]] on a 25-yard touchdown pass, followed by a 75-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Calvin Johnson (American football)|Calvin Johnson]]. Afterwards, Cleveland would end the half with Dawson nailing a 29-yard field goal. Detroit would take the lead in the third quarter with Stafford's 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Will Heller]], the Browns would pick up a safety after Stafford was called for intentional grounding from his own end zone. In the fourth quarter, Cleveland regained the lead with Quinn's 2-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Michael Gaines]] (followed by running back [[Jamal Lewis]] getting a 2-point conversion run). The Lions would take over, and with no time left, Browns safety [[Brodney Pool]] intercepted the ball. However, cornerback [[Hank Poteat]] was flagged for pass interference in the end zone. Since the game cannot end on a defensive penalty, Detroit was given one un-timed down from the Browns' 1 yard line and Stafford completed the game-winning touchdown pass to tight end [[Brandon Pettigrew]]. With the loss, Cleveland fell to 1â9. ==== Week 12: at Cincinnati Bengals ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Browns |R1=0||R2=0||R3=7||R4=0||RT=7 |Home='''Bengals''' |H1=3||H2=10||H3=3||H4=0||HT=16 |stadium= [[Paul Brown Stadium]], [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 59 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 64,553 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 3:11 CIN â [[Shayne Graham|Graham]] 37 yard field goal 3â0 CIN '''2nd Quarter''' * 1:18 CIN â [[J. P. Foschi|Foschi]] 4 yard pass from [[Carson Palmer|Palmer]] (Graham kick) 10â0 CIN * 0:00 CIN â Graham 53 yard field goal 13â0 CIN '''3rd Quarter''' * 6:57 CLE â [[Brady Quinn|Quinn]] 9 yard run ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 13â7 CIN * 0:54 CIN â Graham 28 yard field goal 16â7 CIN }} The Browns headed to Cincinnati to face their in-state rivals in Week 12. The Bengals struck first with 2 field goals by [[Shayne Graham]] and a touchdown reception by [[J. P. Foschi]] in the first half. [[Brady Quinn]] had a touchdown run in the third, but another Bengals field goal and defense put the Browns away. With the loss, the Browns fell to 1â10 and were officially eliminated from postseason contention. ==== Week 13: vs. San Diego Chargers ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Chargers''' |R1=10||R2=3||R3=14||R4=3||RT=30 |Home=Browns |H1=7||H2=0||H3=0||H4=16||HT=23 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 4:05 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 34 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 67,978 |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 8:43 CLE â [[Mohamed Massaquoi|Massaquoi]] 11 yard pass from [[Brady Quinn|Quinn]] ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â0 CLE * 3:03 SD â [[Nate Kaeding|Kaeding]] 32 yard field goal 7â3 CLE * 0:58 SD â [[Mike Tolbert|Tolbert]] 66 yard pass from [[Philip Rivers|Rivers]] (Kaeding kick) 10â7 SD '''2nd Quarter''' * 0:02 SD â Kaeding 42 yard field goal 13â7 SD '''3rd Quarter''' * 10:41 SD â [[Darren Sproles|Sproles]] 31 yard pass from Rivers (Kaeding kick) 20â7 SD * 6:22 SD â [[LaDainian Tomlinson|Tomlinson]] 4 yard run (Kaeding kick) 27â7 SD '''4th Quarter''' * 9:15 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 8 yard pass from Quinn (Dawson kick) 27â14 SD * 4:12 SD â Kaeding 22 yard field goal 30â14 SD * 1:55 CLE â Harrison 8 yard pass from Quinn 30â20 SD * 0:39 CLE â Dawson 49 yard field goal 30â23 SD }} The Browns stayed home in Week 13 to take on the [[San Diego Chargers]]. The Browns struck first with an 11 yard touchdown reception by [[Mohamed Massaquoi]]. The Chargers took the lead back in the first on a field goal by [[Nate Kaeding]] and a long touchdown reception by [[Mike Tolbert]]. San Diego scored 17 more in the second and third, seemingly putting the game out of reach. The Browns managed to get within a touchdown but their comeback ran out of time. With the loss, the Browns fell to 1â11. ==== Week 14: vs. Pittsburgh Steelers ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Steelers |R1=0||R2=3||R3=3||R4=0||RT=6 |Home='''Browns''' |H1=3||H2=10||H3=0||H4=0||HT=13 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 8:20 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 6 Â°F (Clear, very Windy, â15 Â°F wind chill) |attendance= 69,009 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[NFL Network]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Bob Papa]] & [[Matt Millen]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 3:47 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 29 yard field goal 3â0 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 7:20 CLE â Dawson 29 yard field goal 6â0 CLE * 0:41 CLE â [[Chris Jennings|Jennings]] 10 yard run (Dawson kick) 13â0 CLE * 0:00 PIT â [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Reed]] 27 yard field goal 13â3 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 0:08 PIT â Reed 42 yard field goal 13â6 CLE }} The Browns hosted the rival [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] on a night with subzero wind chills for a Week 14 duel. In windy conditions, [[Phil Dawson]] hit a pair of 29 yard field goals, and [[Chris Jennings]] had a 10 yard touchdown run to put the Browns up 13. [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] nailed a field goal before the half to draw the Steelers within 10, and hit another in the third to bring them within a touchdown. However, a scoreless fourth by both teams led the Browns to their first win against the Steelers since 2003, and the Browns became only the fourth team in NFL history to be at least 10 games under .500 and defeat the defending [[Super Bowl]] champions. With the win, the Browns improved to 2â11, snapped a twelve game losing streak against the Steelers, and won their first home game since an October 2008 victory, interestingly against then-defending [[Super Bowl XLII|Super Bowl champion]] [[New York Giants]]. KR Josh Cribbs was named AFC Special Teams Player of the Week.{{cite web|author=Cabot, Mary Kay |date=December 16, 2009 |title= Browns' Josh Cribbs named AFC Special Teams Player of the Week|work=The Plain Dealer|url=http://www.cleveland.com/browns/index.ssf/2009/12/cleveland_browns_josh_cribbs_n.html|accessdate=December 20, 2009}} ==== Week 15: at Kansas City Chiefs ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Browns''' |R1=10||R2=10||R3=7||R4=14||RT=41 |Home=Chiefs |H1=3||H2=21||H3=0||H4=10||HT=34 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/12:00 pm [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 39 Â°F (Partly Sunny) |attendance= 53,315 |referee= [[Gene Steratore]] |TV=[[CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Rich Gannon]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 10:18 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 47 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 4:15 KC â [[Ryan Succop|Succop]] 30 yard field goal 3â3 * 4:12 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 100 yard kickoff return (Dawson kick) 10â3 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 12:36 CLE â Dawson 30 yard field goal 13â3 CLE * 10:09 KC â [[Chris Chambers|Chambers]] 9 yard pass from [[Matt Cassel|Cassel]] (Succop kick) 13â10 CLE * 4:19 KC â [[Jamaal Charles|Charles]] 47 yard run (Succop kick) 17â13 KC * 2:49 KC â [[Andy Studebaker|Studebaker]] fumble recovery in the end zone (Succop kick) 24â13 KC * 2:44 CLE â Cribbs 103 yard kickoff return (Dawson kick) 24â20 KC '''3rd Quarter''' * 13:27 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 71 yard run (Dawson kick) 27â24 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 12:14 CLE â Harrison 8 yard run (Dawson kick) 34â24 CLE * 8:12 KC â Succop 27 yard field goal 34â27 CLE * 2:26 KC â [[Mark Bradley|Bradley]] 12 yard pass from Cassel (Succop kick) 34â34 * 0:52 CLE â Harrison 28 yard run (Dawson kick) 41â34 CLE }} The Browns headed into Kansas City for their last road game of the year to take on the Chiefs in Week 15. The Browns and Chiefs traded field goals in the first quarter, and then Josh Cribbs returned the ensuing kickoff 100 yards for a touchdown, setting an NFL record with his 7th kickoff return for a touchdown. After another [[Phil Dawson]] field goal in the second, the Chiefs scored three straight touchdowns to take a 24â13 lead. However, Cribbs again ran a kickoff back for a touchdown, this time for 103 yards and extending his NFL record to eight kickoff return touchdowns. In the second half, [[Jerome Harrison]] rushed for three touchdowns and amassed a [[filibuster]]-proof majority of his 286 rushing yards. This set a Browns' rushing record for a single game, was the record for most rushing yards in the NFL this season, and was the third most rushing yards in a game in NFL history. [[Matt Cassel]]'s final desperation pass ricocheted off the cross bar, and the Browns defeated the Chiefs 41â34, with their highest point total of the season. With the win, the Browns improved to 3â11 and finished the season 2â6 on the road. Cribbs was named the AFC special teams player of the week for the second straight week.{{cite web|date=December 23, 2009|title= Joshua Cribbs named AFC Special Teams Player of the Week|work=Canton Rep|url=http://www.cantonrep.com/browns/x1689179479/Joshua-Cribbs-named-AFC-Special-Teams-Player-of-the-Week|accessdate=December 23, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==== Holmgren hired as president ==== On December 21, [[Mike Holmgren]] was hired by the Browns to take over as their president. His duties will include personnel management, and he may hire a general manager to assist him. He also will have the power to replace [[Eric Mangini]] as head coach if he so chooses.{{cite web|author=Walker, James |date=December 21, 2009|title= Holmgren agrees to deal with Browns|work=espn.com|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4762828|accessdate=December 21, 2009}} ==== Week 16: vs. Oakland Raiders ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Raiders |R1=3||R2=6||R3=0||R4=0||RT=9 |Home='''Browns''' |H1=10||H2=7||H3=3||H4=3||HT=23 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 34 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 67,964 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Don Criqui]] & [[Randy Cross]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 13:38 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 17 yard run ([[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] kick) 7â0 CLE * 8:22 CLE â Dawson 42 yard field goal 10â0 CLE * 2:53 OAK â [[Sebastian Janikowski|Janikowski]] 44 yard field goal 10â3 CLE '''2nd Quarter''' * 11:16 OAK â Janikowski 34 yard field goal 10â6 CLE * 0:21 CLE â [[Mohamed Massaquoi|Massaquoi]] 19 yard pass from [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Anderson]] (Dawson kick) 17â6 CLE * 0:00 OAK â Janikowski 61 yard field goal 17â9 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 11:11 CLE â Dawson 33 yard field goal 20â9 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 8:35 CLE â Dawson 34 yard field goal 23â9 CLE }} The Browns stayed home in Week 16 for a match with the [[Oakland Raiders]], trying to extend their 2 game winning streak. The Browns struck first with a 17 yard run by [[Jerome Harrison]] and a 42 yard field goal from [[Phil Dawson]]. Oakland kicker [[Sebastian Janikowski]] hit 3 field goals in the first half, including a 61 yarder to close out the half. However, the Browns led at halftime, 17â9. The Browns held the Raiders scoreless in the second half, and Dawson hit 2 more field goals to lead the Browns to a 23â9 victory, their third in a row. With the win, the Browns improved to 4â11. ==== Week 17: vs. Jacksonville Jaguars ==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Jaguars |R1=3||R2=0||R3=0||R4=14||RT=17 |Home='''Browns''' |H1=3||H2=10||H3=7||H4=3||HT=23 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:00 pm [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 16 Â°F (Snow Showers, â1 Â°F Wind Chill) |attendance= 66,935 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] & [[Steve Tasker]] |titlestyle=background-color: #DE6108; color: white; |scoring= '''1st Quarter''' * 11:00 CLE â [[Phil Dawson|Dawson]] 27 yard field goal 3â0 CLE * 2:23 JAC â [[Josh Scobee|Scobee]] 47 yard field goal 3â3 '''2nd Quarter''' * 3:58 CLE â [[Josh Cribbs|Cribbs]] 14 yard run (Dawson kick) 10â3 CLE * 1:46 CLE â Dawson 21 yard field goal 13â3 CLE '''3rd Quarter''' * 4:08 CLE â [[Jerome Harrison|Harrison]] 6 yard run (Dawson kick) 20â3 CLE '''4th Quarter''' * 10:35 JAC â [[Zach Miller (American football b. 1984)|Miller]] 6 yard pass from [[David Garrard|Garrard]] (Scobee kick) 20â10 CLE * 2:20 CLE â Dawson 33 yard field goal 23â10 CLE * 0:00 JAC â Miller 15 yard pass from Garrard (Scobee kick) 23â17 CLE }} The Browns closed out their season at home with a contest against the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]], who came into the game with an outside chance of making the playoffs. Cleveland and Jacksonville traded field goals in the first quarter, but Josh Cribbs broke the tie in the second with a 14 yard touchdown run, and [[Phil Dawson]] added another field goal to give the Browns a 10 point lead at the half. In the third, [[Jerome Harrison]] added a 6 yard touchdown run to push the lead to 17. In the fourth, [[Zach Miller (American football b. 1984)|Zach Miller]] caught a 6 yard pass from [[David Garrard]] to close within 10, but Dawson added another field goal. On the final play of the game (and the season), Miller caught another touchdown pass from Garrard but it was not enough, and the Browns won 23â17. The Browns' 4 game winning streak was the longest since 1994. With the win, the Browns improved to finish the season at 5â11, a one-win improvement over the 2008 campaign. They finished 3â5 at home. ==== KR Cribbs honored ==== On January 6, WR/KR Josh Cribbs was named AFC special teams player of the month for December. During the month, Cribbs earned AFC special teams player of the week honors twice, and set an NFL record with eight career kickoff returns for touchdowns.{{cite news|author=Mike Florio |date=January 6, 2010 |title= Cribbs wins special teams player of the month award |agency=Associated Press |url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2010/01/06/cribbs-wins-special-teams-player-of-the-month-award//story?id=4616312 |accessdate=January 10, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} == 2010 Pro Bowl == KR Josh Cribbs and T [[Joe Thomas (American football)|Joe Thomas]] were recognized for individual accomplishments as they were named to the AFC roster for the [[2010 Pro Bowl]].{{cite web|author=Jackson, Zac|date=December 29, 2009|title=Thomas, Cribbs headed to Pro Bowl|url=http://www.clevelandbrowns.com/article.php?id=10346|accessdate=December 30, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Cribbs, who made his second appearance, was the starting kick and punt returner. Thomas, who made his third consecutive appearance in the game, was selected as the reserve offensive tackle, but started in the game because of an injury to [[Jake Long]] of the [[Miami Dolphins]]. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/cle/2009.htm 2009 Cleveland Browns season at Pro Football Reference] * [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/teams/schedule?team=cle 2009 Cleveland Browns season at ESPN] {{Cleveland Browns}} {{Cleveland Browns seasons}} {{2009 NFL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2009 Cleveland Browns Season}} [[Category:2009 National Football League season by team|Cleveland]] [[Category:Cleveland Browns seasons]]
